model.value: Generic 104-key PC with L-shaped Enter key
BTC 9116U Mini Wireless Internet and Gaming
Logitech G15 extra keys via G15daemon
Logitech iTouch Internet Navigator SE USB

variant.name: altgr-pinyin
variant.description: Hanyu Pinyin Letters (with AltGr dead keys)

variant.name: dvorak_quotes
variant.description: Polish (Dvorak, with Polish quotes on quotemark key)

variant.name: dvorak_altquotes
variant.description: Polish (Dvorak, with Polish quotes on key 1)

variant.name: ast
variant.description: Asturian (Spain, with bottom-dot H and L)

option.value: Caps Lock (while pressed), Alt+Caps Lock for the original Caps Lock action
Caps Lock to first layout; Shift+Caps Lock to second layout
Left Win to first layout; Right Win/Menu to second layout
Left Ctrl to first layout; Right Ctrl to second layout
Both Alts together; AltGr alone chooses third level
Left Ctrl+Left Shift chooses previous layout, Right Ctrl + Right Shift chooses next layout
Left Ctrl+Left Alt chooses previous layout, Right Ctrl + Right Alt chooses next layout
Left Alt+Left Shift chooses previous layout, Right Alt + Right Shift chooses next layout
Ctrl+Left Win to first layout; Ctrl+Menu to second layout
Right Alt; Shift+Right Alt as Compose
Caps Lock; Ctrl+Caps Lock for original Caps Lock action
Caps Lock; acts as onetime lock when pressed together with another 3rd-level chooser
Backslash; acts as onetime lock when pressed together with another 3rd level chooser
The "< >" key; acts as onetime lock when pressed together with another 3rd level chooser
Caps Lock as Ctrl,  Left Control switches to another layout
Caps Lock as Ctrl, Ctrl as Hyper
Swap Left Alt with Left Ctrl
Swap Right Alt with Right Ctrl
Swap Left Win with Left Ctrl
Swap Right Win with Right Ctrl
Left Alt as Ctrl, Left Ctrl as Win, Left Win as Left Alt
Use keyboard LED to show alternative layout
Use keyboard LED to indicate modifiers
Unicode arrows and math operators on default level
Wang 724 keypad with Unicode arrows and math operators
Wang 724 keypad with Unicode arrows and math operators on default level
Four-level key with dot, Latin-9 only
Caps Lock uses internal capitalization; Shift "pauses" Caps Lock
Caps Lock uses internal capitalization; Shift does not affect Caps Lock
Caps Lock acts as Shift with locking; Shift "pauses" Caps Lock
Caps Lock acts as Shift with locking; Shift does not affect Caps Lock
Caps Lock toggles normal capitalization of alphabetic characters
Caps Lock toggles Shift Lock (affects all keys)
Make Caps Lock an additional Esc
Make Caps Lock an additional Esc, but Shift + Caps Lock is the regular Caps Lock
Make Caps Lock an additional Backspace
Make Caps Lock an additional Return key
Make Caps Lock an additional Super
Make Caps Lock an additional Hyper
Make Caps Lock an additional Menu key
Make Caps Lock an additional Num Lock
Make Caps Lock an additional Ctrl and Shift + Caps Lock the regular Caps Lock
Make Caps Lock act as an additional Ctrl modifier, but keep identifying as Caps Lock
Caps Lock gives digits on the digits row (Azerty layouts)
Shift + Caps locks the digits on the digits row, Caps Lock alone behaves as usual (Azerty layouts)
Add the standard behavior to Menu key
Alt and Meta are on Alt
Alt is mapped to Win and the usual Alt
Ctrl is mapped to Win and the usual Ctrl
Ctrl is mapped to Right Win and the usual Ctrl
Ctrl is mapped to Alt, Alt to Win
Meta is mapped to Left Win
Alt is mapped to Right Win, Super to Menu
Left Alt is swapped with Left Win
Right Alt is swapped with Right Win
Win is mapped to PrtSc and the usual Win
Numeric keypad always enters digits (as in macOS)
Num Lock on: digits; Shift for arrows. Num Lock off: arrows (as in Windows)
Shift does not cancel Num Lock, chooses 3rd level instead
Map Hyper to Mod2 (conflict with NumLock)
Map Hyper to Mod3 (conflict with LevelFive)
Map Hyper to Mod4 (conflict with Super)
Special keys (Ctrl+Alt+<key>) handled in a server
Apple Aluminium emulates Pause, PrtSc, Scroll Lock
Japanese Apple keyboards emulate OADG109A backslash
Japanese Apple keyboards emulate PC106 backslash
Both Shifts together enable Caps Lock
Both Shifts together enable Caps Lock; one Shift key disables it
Both Shifts together enable Shift Lock
Allow breaking grabs with keyboard actions (warning: security risk)
Allow grab and window tree logging
The "< >" key chooses 5th level and acts as a one-time lock if pressed with another 5th level chooser
Right Alt chooses 5th level and acts as a one-time lock if pressed with another 5th level chooser
Left Win chooses 5th level and acts as a one-time lock if pressed with another 5th level chooser
Right Win chooses 5th level and acts as a one-time lock if pressed with another 5th level chooser
Non-breaking space at the 3rd level, thin non-breaking space at the 4th level
Non-breaking space at the 4th level, thin non-breaking space at the 6th level
Non-breaking space at the 4th level, thin non-breaking space at the 6th level (via Ctrl+Shift)
Zero-width non-joiner at the 2nd level, zero-width joiner at the 3rd level
Zero-width non-joiner at the 2nd level, zero-width joiner at the 3rd level, non-breaking space at the 4th level
Zero-width non-joiner at the 2nd level, non-breaking space at the 3rd level
Zero-width non-joiner at the 2nd level, non-breaking space at the 3rd level, zero-width joiner at the 4th level
Zero-width non-joiner at the 2nd level, non-breaking space at the 3rd level, thin non-breaking space at the 4th level
Zero-width non-joiner at the 3rd level, zero-width joiner at the 4th level

Make right Ctrl a Hangul key

Make right Ctrl a Hanja key
At the corresponding key in a QWERTY layout
